Posts.Content: SLH wrote: Hi gals, I had a consultation with a ps yesterday and I've scheduled a January deconstruction.  I told him that if I was in my thirties, or even forties, having breasts would mean more to me.  But I'm 54.  Having my physical strength and being comfortable again is my goal. I've had muscle pain from the expanders, and then saline implants, since March 2005.  I don't regret this experience, because I think I needed to go through this in order to be content with a completely flat chest. I'm curious to know how implants are "installed", because the dr told me that he will not be able to take parts of the reconstruction out.  It sounds like they glue a platform, or capsule, to the ribs that can't be taken off. I told him I wanted to be as neatly flat and symmetrical as possible, and that it seemed to me that it would be best if he took out the implants, and then gave me a couple months to tighten my muscles back up before he excised the loose skin.  He said that sounded right, but would have to check on whether insurance would pay for two operations. I'm so looking forward to losing "weight" in the New Year! sally  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Fed up with foobs SLH SLH

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2007 11:11PM SLH wrote: The books that I've read about reconstruction don't say precisely how they attach the implant to the ribcage. But the info from the ps about the removal says: "Whether the fibrous capsule, which always forms around the implant, can be removed depends on whether the placement of the prosthesis had been under the muscle or not.  The capsule against the ribs cannot be removed, but whatever can be removed will be." The ps said that the capsule molds itself onto the ribcage.  So that must be what makes the permanent irregular ridge. Honestly, it will be hard to see myself without breasts.  I won't miss my saggy-fed-3-kids-50-yr-old pair as much as my perky-perfect-25-yr-old ones! But I'm looking forward to feeling comfortable again. Thanks for your encouraging words! sally
Posts.Title: Fed up with foobs SLH SLH

Your surgery tomorrow sounds like it won't be the full anesthesia, which is good.  And maybe if they can lessen your pain it will give you a much needed break. Take care, sally

Posts.Content: May 5, 2008 07:38AM SLH wrote: Oww.  That's rough Anne. I didn't have nerve pain with my reconstruction, just muscle pain.  But I've had several nerve problems in the past.  After my first abdominal surgery (vertical scar from belly button down) I had a nerve problem that was so painful just accidently touching my stomach against anything would make me cry.  I also had nerve pain when a dog bit me severely on my arm.  And after my bilateral my whole chest felt like pins and needles. Each time it took awhile for the nerves to calm down and go back to normal.  For the one on my stomach, I did have a dr inject the spot with 6 shots of novocaine (or something) when it was esp bad. I hope you get some relief soon.  Do take it easy.  When I had my implants removed a couple months ago, my surgeon said not to exercise for a month.  That's probably conservative, but "mradf" posted this week with severe problems after trying to lift heavy things during her recon. Take care of yourself. sally

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2008 10:34PM - edited Jan 12, 2008 10:44PM by SLH Hi Daisy, Crazy your not. It's good to find out the facts before jumping in.  Doctors sometimes sell the lumpectomy as a less invasive procedure than a mastectomy.  But the accompanying rads often cause complications that are not expected.  If the cancer comes back in the breast and you need to have a mastectomy, then rads often make reconstruction difficult or impossible. They can also cause lymphedema. With a mastecomy they might also recommend rads depending on the location of the cancerous cells, but often not. There are a lot of women on this site who have debated the decisions that you are struggling with. You're not alone. sally Do a search on inshock.  She also has DCIS stage 0.
Posts.Title: What do I do?? crazydaisy crazydaisy

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2008 01:31PM SLH wrote: Hi Prycylla, Six years ago my mom (at age 80) had surgery for ovarian cancer.  The surgical oncologist came to her bedside at midnight, and without any family members around, told her that the cancer had spread and that she shouldn't bother with chemo, because she was going to die soon.  She had to wait until we got there in the morning to talk to anyone about it.  He was a heartless doctor, so we found another for her. She has been taking chemo off and on since then.  She doesn't have a curable cancer, but she hasn't done badly with chemo treatments.  And she has had six years with her youngest grandson, who was only 3 months old when she had her surgery. Your mom's cancer may not be as difficult to treat because she is post-menopause and her cells aren't growing as fast.  Chemo used to be so much worse than it is now. I hope for the best for your mom. sally

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2007 04:16PM SLH wrote: Thanks for sharing, Riverwoman! I also had a tiny bitsy ILC on one side, but really knew I needed the whole darn bilat bonanza. I had two surgeons tell me no, but with my list of reasons why I wanted a bilat in hand, I found a dr who agreed. I did do the expander/implant recon, have had trouble with it for over two years, and am trying to get up the nerve to throw off these great balls of water! Seriously, I'm wondering if the implants will hide returning tumors. My onc is kind of vague about how I'm supposed to find signs of cancer. Mammograms won't work, and he said x-rays would just expose me to more radiation?#@! Your brave and gutsy! I admire that! Sally
Posts.Title: Thank all that is good and right in the world! Riverwoman Riverwoman

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2007 11:17PM SLH wrote: I was 51 when I had a bilateral for stage 1 ILC. I hadn't started menopause, so my onc thought it would be wise for me to have a complete hysterectomy for many reasons: 1) Family history.  My mom has ovarian c, my sister has bc. 2) I have Factor 5 Leiden, a fairly common, genetic blood-clotting element 3) Tamoxifen has a higher risk for blood clots than an AI 4) Women who have bc have a higher risk for ovarian & endometrial cancers For me, the abdominal hysterectomy was a quick decision, because I've watched my mom suffer with ovarian cancer for 5 years. It was an easy surgery, compared to my bilateral, and I don't miss the monthly "curse"!
Posts.Title: Ovariectomy Decision simonet Daudine

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2008 04:44PM SLH wrote: Hi... there's a lot of women who do the oophorectomy or hysterectomy.  If your bc is estrogen +, or you have the BRCA gene, then you have a higher risk of getting ovarian, uterine, or endometrial cancer. I was 51 when I was dx, but I was premenopause.  My onc wanted me on Arimidex, which can only be taken after meno.  Plus my mom has ovarian c, so I had the full hysterectomy. sally

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2008 03:08AM - edited Jun 13, 2008 06:22AM by SLH Hi Marilyn, As Beesie said, it sounds like your med group was taking a lot of time and effort to give you excellent care.  "Dense space" can be Invasive Lobular Cancer which doesn't form a lump like Ductal cancer.  It's harder to diagnose and will often be more advanced because it's more like a thickening in the breast. Unfortunately, 41 doesn't seem young for bc anymore.  We have sisters here who are as young as 18. I'm hoping this is a benign scare for you and you won't have to join our club.  Come back and let us know how you're doing. Take care, sally
Posts.Title: Hi, new and mad!!!! stevemorse SLH

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 03:58AM SLH wrote: Sorry Marilyn, I didn't mean to scare you.  But all women need to know that there are several kinds of cancer that never form lumps. We all hate cancer.  Go ahead and be angry at cancer that @*#%s our bodies, @*#%s our lives, @*#%s our careers, @*#%s our relationships. But don't be angry at health professionals who take the time to investigate suspicious signs.  Believe me, the "wait and watch" treatment plan is much harder to deal with. sally
Posts.Title: Hi, new and mad!!!! stevemorse SLH

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2009 10:42AM SLH wrote: When I had the excisional biopsy 7 years ago, the surgeon recommended it over a needle biopsy, saying that if a lump is too small or too hard for a needle to penetrate, that it can produce a false negative result.  She said they tag the lump as benign then, and it can be passed over for later tests. I also had another lump tested with a needle biopsy that was a fast-growing, fluid-filled cyst, which might be what yours is, Justelle. Now that needle biopsy testing has improved and they do MRI-guided tests, I can see that taking the whole lump could cause scarring and complications for later sentinel node injections. Justelle, whatever biopsy you choose, take it easy with physical labor afterwards for a couple weeks.  Let your tissues heal and avoid hematomas.
Posts.Title: Reality check justelle justelle

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2009 01:42PM SLH wrote: About 7 years ago I had a lump removed.  I didn't have nodes removed, so although it was general anesthetic, it was pretty quick and easy. No BC, no complications. Then 4 years ago I was diagnosed with BC.  Before my bilateral they did a deep MRI-guided needle biopsy.  A couple days afterwards I did yard work and heavy lifting.  My whole breast turned dark purple from a hematoma.  It didn't really matter, because I had it off a week later anyway. In my opinion, you should be able to host the party.  But try not to lift heavy things.  The tissues are damaged and blood vessels can break, so take it easy.  Good luck on your biopsy!

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2008 11:18AM SLH wrote: Hi samcid, I had stage 1 ILC. I had bilateral w/reconstruction, then complete hysterectomy. My onc recommended this because there is an increased chance of getting ovarian, endometrial, and uterine cancers if you have bc. In my case, my mom has ovarian, and my sister has bc, so I have even more chance. Also, I was premenstrual so I couldn't go on an AI. I would have had to take tamoxifen, which has a much higher chance of blood clots. I have a common genetic increased risk anyway (called Factor 5 Leiden), so my chance of getting clots was high. I haven't had problems in the 2 years I've been on Arimidex. sally

Posts.Title: Happy Mother's Day! LuAnnH LuAnnH

Posts.Content: May 13, 2008 12:15PM SLH wrote: Hi Kira, I was diagnosed in 2005 with lobular cancer Feb 2 and had a bilateral March 12.  The first surgeon I saw recommended lumpectomy with the required radiation.  I called back to schedule it, and said if the cancer came back I would want to have a mastectomy with immediate reconstruction.  She said that recon would be impossible after radiation.  That's when I realized I needed to research my options. If you go through the surgery this week you probably will feel very sore for the wedding, lumpectomy or mastectomy.  Unfortunately, there is always the chance of complications.  But even if it is problem-free, I don't think many of us would have been able to hug hundreds of people, dance all night, and do the multi-tasking that is required of a bride's mom after our surgeries. Also, there are women here who have had complications from trying to do too much too soon.  With a mast. you will have a tube draining the fluid out for at least a week, but even if it is a lumpectomy with sentinal node removal only, the tissues are cut, so you really can't lift anything or do any vigorous movement with your arm for awhile.  Many of us have had hematomas because we did. I  think you will be happier waiting until after the wedding for your surgery.  We all want to forge ahead and rid our bodies of cancer and our minds of the worry, but first be happy at your daughter's wedding. sally

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2007 06:58PM SLH wrote: Hi gscott, Over the years I'd had 3 lumps I could feel, that turned out benign.  The last one was HUGE, about 1" across, and grew quickly.  Because of it, I had a higher resolution mammogram, and they could see that it was a fluid-filled cyst that they easily aspirated by drawing the fluid out with a needle. But the high res also picked up a spot on the outer edge of my other breast that turned out to be a stage 1 ILC.  The year before my sister had bc, and my mom has ovarian c. It sounds like yours might be a cyst.  But with your family history, stay vigilant! sally

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2008 04:06AM SLH wrote: Hi cmb, I can't help you with your recon question, but I just want to give you a shoulder to rant on! When I was dx with stage 1 ILC, my surgeon strongly recommended lumpectomy with the mandatory radiation.  I thought about it for a few hours, then called her back to schedule it.  I told her if the cancer came back, I would want to have a mastectomy and immediate reconstruction.  She said "Oh no. After radiation you won't be able to have reconstruction."!!!  I hadn't cried when I was diagnosed, but I cried then when I realized I had almost made a decision not knowing much about cancer and treatments.  It was a shock to me that a surgeon was telling me that this would be the least invasive procedure, when in fact radiation can cause reconstruction problems and lymphedema. There are many women here who have done recon after rads, some successful, some not.  I had a bilateral w/immediate recon (no rads), and I ended up having my implants removed after 3 years and going flat. Take care, sally

Posts.Title: Silent Dread SLH snowyday

Posts.Content: SLH wrote: Everything about cancer SUCKS!  But one thing that is so hard is the worrying in silence. Since my bilateral 3 years ago, I've had pea-sized lumps form twice on my chest that turned out benign.  Then I've had a punch-in-the-stomach pain since last Nov that I finally couldn't stand the worry any more, so they gave me an ultrasound.  I was hoping it was gallstones, but I was afraid it was my liver.  They didn't see anything. Now I have a pea-sized lump in the jugular lymph node on the side of my neck.  I saw my onc last week and he said to wait-and-watch for 6 weeks. Each time I'm filled with anxiety, but I can't tell anyone.  I esp wouldn't tell my husband and kids, or my mom and make them worry.  But the anxiety is overwhelming. sally  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Silent Dread SLH snowyday

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2008 07:41PM - edited Apr 29, 2008 07:42PM by SLH Thanks, guys. I asked my onc a year ago whether I should have scans done, and he said that the treatment was the same whether caught early with scans or catching the mets when they became symptomatic.  It doesn't make sense to me to wait for pain or shortness of breath, but then I read that you can be over-exposed to radiation from CT scans, so I didn't insist. Last week when I found the lump on my neck, he did seem concerned.  He said that bc would normally go to the supraclavicular lymph node, not the jugular lymph node.  Mine is on the side of my neck, under my ear. But I think I'll schedule an appointment for a scan because it feels like a second lump is forming.  It can't be good. sally
Posts.Title: Silent Dread SLH snowyday

Posts.Content: May 12, 2008 02:43PM SLH wrote: Annie,  I think you need to watch your thyroid because of the exposure also.  My dad was about 10 when 3 of his siblings had TB.  He had x-rays every 6 months for years.  He never had TB, but he got thyroid cancer which metastasized to his lungs.  Thyroid c is strongly linked to radiation exposure.  It's one of the easiest cancers to cure if it's caught early. I think my bc was from working with paint thinners and benzene products.  To clean up after oil painting we would wash our brushes and hands in toxic chemicals, and as a graphic designer I would clean my desk and art with benzene.  I wonder how many artists have bc? sally
Posts.Title: Anyone else in this category? HeatherBLocklear Shirlann

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2008 12:10AM SLH wrote: Thank you all for your letters. Sometimes I have mixed feelings about being involved with BC.Org.  I cry over some of the personal stories, and wish I knew the perfect words to respond when letters are full of pain and fear.  But I come back because I know I can say things here that I can't say to friends and family, and all of you know exactly how I feel. Cheryl, one of the reasons why I chose a bilateral when I had stage 1 ILC was that I had lumpy breasts.  I had two cysts biopsied on my "good" side before they found my ca. And when they did the pathology report on my breast tissue after my mastectomy, they found 5 more benign cysts that would have required biopsies. Surgery, chemo, radiation...they're all hurdles to get over.  But the neverending worry is exhausting. sally

I take a Dulcolax or Colace (stool softener) every time I take a major pain pill. Yes, I learned the "hard" way! (pun intended)

Posts.Title: mets to abdominal lymph nodes?? Diana_B Mara5

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2008 11:50AM SLH wrote: Hi Susan, I have looked into this a little.  My oldest sister has IDC, I have ILC, my mom has ovarian c, my younger sister had thyroid cancer, and my dad died of thyroid cancer 25 years ago. There is a direct association between breast and ovarian cancer, but they are still researching a link between thyroid and breast. "A review of the literature on the relationship between thyroid disorders and breast cancer does not provide conclusive evidence for the establishment of a causal relationship as breast cancer has been associated with hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism and nontoxic goiter. Most reports on the association of thyroid enlargement and breast cancer have emanated from areas of endemic iodine deficiency and these reports have relied on neck palpation. The contribution of the present study is in the application of the highly sensitive technique of diagnostic ultrasound to the investigation of subtle changes in thyroid volume and anatomy in patients with breast cancer. The mean thyroid volume of 20.4 +/- 1.0 ml in 184 breast cancer patients was significantly greater than that of 12.9 +/- 1.2 ml in age-matched controls (p < 0.01). Also the number of individual patients with breast cancer having enlarged thyroid glands (73/184; 39.7%) was significantly greater than the corresponding number (13/150; 8.6%) in the control group (p < 0.001). There was a direct correlation between thyroid enlargement and breast tumour staging. Both mean thyroid volume and % of enlarged thyroids were identical in groups of patients scanned after (Retrospective Group) and before (Prospective Group) various therapies for breast cancer, thus excluding therapeutic intervention as a cause for thyroid enlargement. The results indicate a direct relationship between the two disorders perhaps involving a common growth stimulus and emphasise the importance of raising the consciousness of the coincidence of both disorders." It sounds like the connection might be the genetic factors that cause breast cancer might also cause thyroid enlargement and cancer, such as low antibodies for cancers and accelerated cell growth.  And treatments for one cancer might start the other, such as the iodine therapy for thyroid c triggers breast c, and the radiation for breast c causes thyroid c. The bottom line is that all women who have one should be vigilant for the other.  And the "good" thing about thyroid cancer is that it is one of the easiest cancers to detect and cure.  My dad ignored symptoms and was misdiagnosed for years, whereas my sister found hers early on and is cancer-free. sally
Posts.Title: Thyroid Nodule? Msklapkin Honeybear

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2008 05:35PM SLH wrote: Hi again, I just wanted to add a few more thoughts.  Pick a non-romantic time when you're both sitting around talking.  Then say something like...This is hard for me to say, but I'm worried that you might have a lump in your breast.  I love you and I want you to have it checked out. It may be an awkward moment, but there are two scenarios that would be worse: 1...That you stop touching her breast because it makes you uncomfortable to be reminded of it. 2...That you don't say anything, and a year from now she finds she has breast cancer.  You would feel so incredibly guilty. As I said, it probably is just a cyst.  But there are 20-yr-olds getting bc these days.  So love her by looking out for her. sally
Posts.Title: Help - how to raise topic with girlfriend... anxiousboyfriend Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2008 07:03PM SLH wrote: Hi Jacqui, I've been through a lot of surgeries and procedures, even before getting breast cancer.  Needles are tough, even for the "pros" like me.  Some doctors and nurses will tell you that they can't use a numbing solution, but they can.  The best IV I've ever had (and I've had a couple hundred!) was numbed first with a little injection of lidocaine. If I were you, I would first tell them that you are sensitive to needles and pain (everyone has varying pain tolerance). State it clearly, without whining or tears.  Ask for a topical numbing solution (they rub it on).  Then request an injection of lidocaine before the IV is put in.  The nurses will say that it makes it harder, because it restricts the blood vessels, but they can do it.  If you are at the hospital, you can also request the IV specialist. The nurses also might balk at this, because it slows the schedule down. If you feel very fearful, ask your dr if you can take a sedative orally, and have someone drive you to and from the tests. Especially request a topical anesthesia before the sentinel node biopsy injections the day before your surgery. You will find that you're tougher than you think. sally
Posts.Title: I'm afraid of needles & need a masectomy! jacquibutterfly Momine

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2008 02:41AM SLH wrote: Hi Jeanette, I had immediate expanders placed during my bilateral surgery, so I had a few more issues with muscle spasms.  But I can tell you that it seems to get worse before it gets better.  It was an awful feeling of numbness first, and then an over-sensitivity as the nerves regenerated.  That slowly goes away, as does the cording.  My bilateral was 3 years ago, but I just had a painful cord occur that ran from my scar to my waist.  It lasted for about a month, and then went away. Keep up the stretching and yoga helps too.  Going without recon will help you heal quickly. Take care, sally

The vet just called and they found a mass in his neck. sally

But now they might feel differently because their middle school Principal has been amazing this year with her cancer.  She was diagnosed last August, so she opened the school year, then took a month off to have a bilateral, and while working part-time started her chemo and is undergoing reconstruction.  She goes around school completely bald.  They see how she is unembarrassed by it.  A tough woman around teenagers. sally

After a week you'll feel better, but then the nerve ending sensitivity will hit you.  It can be pretty scary.  Your chest will feel too sensitive for anything to touch it.  But it goes away, and you'll even get sort of normal feeling skin one day.  Take care. sally

Now I have a pea-sized lump in the jugular lymph node on the side of my neck.  I saw my onc last week and he said to wait-and-watch for 6 weeks. Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2008 01:07AM SLH wrote: Hi Otter, My own story starts with lobular cancer, stage 1.  The first dr I saw strongly recommended a lumpectomy w/radiation. So I scheduled it, and said that if the cancer came back, I would opt for a mastectomy with reconstruction. She replied that the rads would probably make recon impossible. It scared me that I almost jumped into a life-changing surgery without knowing anything about it.  So I did my research, wrote myself a list, and found a surgeon that agreed to give me a bilateral. My list: 1. Lobular more often jumps to the other side 2. My "good" breast was very lumpy and would have meant unending biopsies 3. With one clear side I have an uncompromised arm for blood pressure and IVs 4. I didn't want radiation that is required with lumpectomies 5. I felt that I was lucky the first time to have found it so early, and might not be so lucky again 6. Family: my mom has ovarian c, my sister has IDC 7. I was premenopause, so more estrogen feeding the cancer 8. The younger you are, the more time after the first diagnosis for having it come back in the other breast I'm not sorry for losing both at once.  I did not have to do chemo or rads.  I'm taking Arimidex, but haven't had many side effects. For your own peace of mind, write down your reasons for making your decision so you can read it again when the going gets tough.  sally
Posts.Title: Feeling pressured to have lumpectomy instead of mastectomy otter irishdreama

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2008 07:58AM - edited Feb 10, 2008 07:59AM by SLH Hi Hannahbanana, I had lobular, not Paget's, but I wanted to tell you what Dr. Susan Love says about Paget's in her book: "There are probably two variants of Paget's disease: one associated with an invasive cancer in the breast and one that involves only the nipple.  The former would be treated as any invasive cancer would.  If the invasive cancer lump is far from the nipple, a mastectomy may be necessary to get both areas out; otherwise wide excision and radiation is a reasonable alternative." Paget's disease that involves only the nipple has a better prognosis than regular breast cancer.  It doesn't tend to be too aggressive, and usually the lymph nodes turn out to be negative.  Until recently most doctors assumed that you needed a mastectomy--they seemed to think that if you couldn't keep your nipple, your breast didn't matter.  Most women, of course, know better." "This has been a campaign of mine, and a few years ago some of us managed to convince the rest of the medical establishment that all that was needed was to remove the nipple and areola, and that many women prefer to keep the rest of the breast if they can.  True, your breast looks a bit funny after the nipple's been removed--but it is still there.  An artificial nipple can be made by a plastic surgeon.  Many women, however, don't mind the way the breast looks as long as they look natural in a bra.  Some of my patients with this kind of Paget's disease chose plastic surgery, and some didn't bother with it." She does say that Paget's can often be associated with ductal carcinoma in situ, which is often treated with a mastectomy. So that is good news for you if it only involves your nipple.  I guess I would push for an MRI, and tests to be sure there is no DCIS, for your peace of mind. Take care, sally
Posts.Title: Paget's breast cancer Hannahbanana Hannahbanana

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2007 12:49AM - edited Oct 29, 2007 12:55AM by SLH My ILC was found at Stage 1, but I chose a bilateral because of many reasons. I wrote them down so that if I ever felt doubt that I had made the wrong decision I could read my list again. I didn't have to do chemo or rads, but I had 4 surgeries in a year. I felt glad that I had removed my good breast before a reoccurence of cancer on that side, because I didn't have to have lymph nodes removed, and therefore I had an arm for blood pressure and IV lines. I probably have the BRCA gene, but haven't been tested. Mt mom has ovarian c, and my sis bc. Unfortunately, I didn't research all options on reconstruction, because the ps that was highly recommended to me said my best option was expanders, then implants. I didn't have rads, but I've still had problems with my muscles being stretched out so far. Investigate all procedures. sally
Posts.Title: Debating a Bilat! Need Advice/Recommendations! tampachick Beesie

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2008 04:24PM SLH wrote: Hi Janet, I'd like to add a couple thoughts to ease your mom's worries.  For one, usually cancer can't be moved around.  That usually is a fluid-filled cyst.  And two, even if it is cancer, at 81 cells would be growing very slowly, so it wouldn't be a difficult cancer to contain.  It's always stressful, but it will be OK. sally
Posts.Title: Concern for 81 yo mom NYJanet NYJanet

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2008 03:03PM SLH wrote: Hi again Jacqui, The "mum" was a giveaway!  You live in a beautiful area, but it might be best for you to go to a breast center in a larger city for the biopsy and diagnosis.  My mom lives in a little town on the Oregon coast (where I grew up) that is very much like parts of England.  She has had ovarian cancer for the past 6 years, and her initial diagnosis and surgery was in the town's little local hospital.  It would have been better if she would have been at a larger facility. Small hospitals are fine for getting your chemo treatments and radiation, but they may not have the best and most current diagnostic tools. The tests they use now are very sophisticated. They can tell by testing the tumor whether the cancer will respond to hormone drugs alone, or whether you require chemo.  That is a HUGE deal.  Chemo is a very harsh treatment, and if there is a chance you don't need it, then you don't want it! Your family needs you.  One hard thing about cancer is that you feel better before treatment begins.  It's deceptive, but you can't ignore it. Go for it, Jacqui!  Take a trip to London, (or France?) and get this beast under control! sally

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2008 12:11PM SLH wrote: Hi embmom, The key words in your letter: "I'm a pretty plucky strong thing" say a lot about how well you will deal with treatment.  Also, having a sense of humor helps! We all have our blue days and our tired days.  If you can find someone you trust to help out in your shop, you shouldn't close down.  My kids' middle school Principal just finished her chemo, and is going through reconstruction for her bilateral, and continued to work throughout.  She's tough! Plan on taking some time off for your surgery.  If you don't do reconstruction you will recover more quickly. From what I've read in the "No-Recon" section, the women are feeling pretty good in a matter of weeks.  But all the various recons take time to heal and more follow-up surgeries.  It's one of the many difficult decisions you will face. Take care, sally
Posts.Title: just back from the biopsy embmom HeatherBLocklear

Posts.Content: May 15, 2008 03:29PM - edited May 15, 2008 03:30PM by SLH Hi Vivian, Most of my no-recon friends here know my story, so Ill be brief. Three years ago I chose a bilateral w/immediate expanders.  Six months later I had the exchange surgery to saline implants.  The whole process of stretching my muscles out during the expansion messed up my chest, arm, and esp neck muscles.  So this last January I had surgery to take out the implants and remove the excess skin. Although I still have pain in my neck that probably is permanent, I don't have that horrible tight feeling down the sides of my neck, and the feeling like my foobs are squishing under my arms when I lift anything heavy. I was also having problems with muscle contractions (esp when I was trying to get to sleep) around the implants, which might have been the start of capsular contracture. My foobs looked fine, but a large part of sexiness is feeling good.  For me, being in pain wasn't sexy. sally

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2008 04:38PM SLH wrote: I think you need to speak up and encourage her to get it checked out.  Odds are it will be just a benign cyst, but the sooner the better if it is cancer. My sister-in-law is a hair dresser and was cutting a guy's hair when she spotted a large mole covered by his hair.  She told him it looked suspicious, and that he should have it checked out.  It was a melanoma, and she possibly saved his life. sally
Posts.Title: Help - how to raise topic with girlfriend... anxiousboyfriend Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2008 10:50PM SLH wrote: Hi again Jacquibutterfly, Have you seen a good, qualified breast surgeon and had some diagnostic testing? Before they start scheduling a mastectomy, they need to find out some things about your cancer. Cancer cells have all kinds of "personality":  Ductal grows in identifiable lumps, Lobular often reoccurs in the other breast, Tubular is slow-growing...etc. But yours seems to have grown very quickly.  If it is IBC, Inflammatory Breast Cancer, then the treatment calls for chemo first, and probably radiation, to shrink the tumor first before any surgery. Are you in the UK?  It's very important to find out the kind of cancer first for you to make the right decision about treatment.  If you can do that, the women on this site can help you understand what the results mean, and what your options are for treatment. Be brave.  It's a scary time, but it will get better. sally

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2008 04:34PM - edited Apr 1, 2008 04:35PM by SLH Hi Dawn, There are no set-in-stone reasons for getting lymphedema, although we all need to take precautions. Sometimes the "least invasive" surgery of lumpectomy + radiation will cause it. I had a bilateral w/expanders, plus 4 nodes taken out of my left side.  Six months later I had my exchange surgery, a month after that a hysterectomy.  Then six months later I had scar tissue from my hysterectomy wrap around my intestines and had emergency abdominal surgery.  I came out of anesthesia with an auto BP compressor on my "bad" left arm.  It was on all night. Two months later, I gently picked up what I thought was a nice cat, and it buried its teeth into my "bad" arm for a minute.  I ended up with a GIGANTIC infection and two days in the hospital with IV antibiotics.  My arm was swollen from my fingertips to my elbow with red lines going up to my shoulder. But I didn't get lymphedema.  With my luck, I'm keeping my fingers crossed for the rest of my life! sally

Posts.Title: The Fun Keeps on Coming smithlme smithlme

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2008 12:20PM SLH wrote: Hi Gnovian, I wanted to tell you a couple things. My mom has had ovarian cancer for 6 years, dx when she was 80.  She had the physical stamina of a 60-yr-old when she started, and she did really well through the surgery, but the continuing chemo treatments have been rough on her. Also, my mom had scar tissue from the original surgery that blocked her intestines, so she had emergency abdominal surgery 2 years ago. For those 8 days in the hospital, my mom went completely "crazy"--hallucinating, trying to jump out of bed, didn't know where she was or why her stomach hurt. Maybe the chemo influenced this, but the drs said it happens sometimes when elderly people have surgery.  We had to watch her 24/7 in the hospital.  The day the drs signed the release form to let her go home, she snapped out of it.  She suddenly was mentally back, but didn't remember any of the past 8 days. If your mom could do surgery only, and avoid chemo, it would help her mentally. Breast surgery isn't quite as harsh as abdominal surgery, so the anesthesia won't be as bad. Take care,  sally
